Corked bottle, dark amber brown with no head, aroma is dark fruits, flavor has a lot of,dark fruit, chocolate , rye bread, odder than it sounds with plastic malty fruit finish

dark brown with some ruby tones, big off white head. Lots of sugary sweet grape drink in the aroma, some dark fruit, booze. Peppery alcohol floating around on the tongue, almost herbal like qualities floating around in here as well. Finish is mildly sweet, boozy, big. Damn good for such a boring style.

no idea what all Im smellingsour plum. dried plum, sugar, alcohol. so soothing in mouth and throat. modest khaki head in impenetrable dark umber. flavor sweet but not cloying, a little riffle of woody hops, otehrwise plums, syrup, a little smoke. sweet finish.

Beautiful packaging, corked n caged. Pours deep mahogany with a cream tan head. Served Room temp, deep and gorgeous chocolate cake, raison, and plum juice aroma, oh my. Slightly tart yet sweet and decadent. Will be aging a few of these on da real.

From a corked and caged bottle shared with Westchesterco and Ryan.  Pours a cloudy cola brown with an off white head.  Aroma of raisins and dark fruits.  Flavors include some chocolate, caramel, raisin and plum.  Quite nice.

Bottle. 3/23/13. Pours a deep brown-red with a bubbly, effervescent ligght-brown head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, candi, bubblegum, an amazing rich plum character, other dark fruits, spice, floral. Taste is sweet, spicy, fruity, tart, grapes, dark fruit, PLUMS, bready. Im shocked to say that the Belgian yeast isnt too aggressive in the taste. Very subtle here; I am not used to that out of most Belgian styles Ive had. Some really nice lacing. Medium carbonation. Full, coating mouth feel. Well-hidden alcohol. Worth picking up!

Comes out of the tap a rich, warm coffee brown with a decent, if not overly, persistent tan head that leaves generous lacing. Robust aroma has an overtone of plum and malty, banana and earthy notes. Satisfying flavor has a hearty fruity tone, plum plus some banana, as well as earthy, nutty and malty tones and an appreciable alcohol nip. Firm, thick texture leaves a fizzy, earthy, fruity and slightly woody finish. Let this sugar plum dance on your tongue.

3/21/13. 375mL bottle thanks to Cheesemoose! Brown pour with a small frothy head. Rich fruity aroma with lots of dark fruits and rich caramel malts. Rich dark fruit flavor as well, lightly sweet. Nice.

375 ml corked and caged bottle (comes in 4 pack). Pours a medium brown with beige head. Smells of sweet malts, prunes/raisins/plums.  Tastes sweet caramel malts with notes of dried dark fruit and plums.  high alcohol malty sweetness with this 10.2% alc beer. Incredible complexity, taste goes on and on on the palate.  must try.

375 corked and caged bottle. Pours a medium, well retained, light beige, tiny bubbled head, with some lacing, over a clear, reddish brown (SRM 20) body.....nose is sweet malts, toffee/caramel,  with hints of plum, raisin, spice....taste is sweet toffee/caramel with plum, raisin, light clove, hints of allspice, finishing with a light spice/hop bitterness....mouth feel light of medium, sticky, alcohol warmth present, carbonation low. This falls well within the Abt/Quad style, with lovely complexity and depth in both aroma and flavor. BJCP 9/3/16/4/8

375ml bottle shared with wife pours crystal ruby amber capped by a small dark cream hue head with fair retention. Nose oozes plums and booze. Taste is sweet with burnt sugar, plum, and other dark pit fruits. Body is bold, burly, and creamy.

Bottle. Mahogony beer with a dark cream head. Dried fruit and yeast aroma with earthiness. Dried fruit and malt flavor with yeast and spice. Medium bodied. Dried fruit and dark fruit lingers with spice, yeast, and malt.

Draft.  Cola black body with medium beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, plum, alcohol, light caramel.  Taste is sweet, plum, caramel, some alcohol/alcohol warming.  Sticky medium-full body, minimal carbonation.

12oz cork and cage, pours a cola color with a creamy looking khaki head. Aroma is great, complex with layers, bready, spicy belgian yeast, boozey, lots of dark fruits, plums, figs, heavy malt. Flavor is nice very malty with sweet bread, some caramel/tofffee notes, plum , fig and cherry just like the aroma, Im surprised at how much you really do notice the plum taste, belgian spice in the finish with a tiny bit of a medicinal finish. Nice.

Pours an exceptionally dark brown color with big head that rises and falls into a thin-ish film but never really goes away. 

The aroma is richly malty, very nutty and far roastier than what Im used to in a quad... but its a very enjoyable characteristic. Some raisins and dark fruit in there as well, but this is more subdued than the malty bit. The beer is not especially sweet smelling. 

The flavor is somewhere between a huge brown ale and a quad, certainly nutty and roasty but never "coffee, or burnt" roasty just defiantly roasty. The grapey alcohol note is hit pretty perfectly and I cant tell if the spiciness is alcohol deriven, spice deriven or both. Either way the booziness is pretty big. The plum flavor is nice, fairly subdued but very well integrated, the level of sweetness is good... this isnt exactly a style of beer that lends its self to dryness, and this is by no means not sweet... but its a long ways from cloying or sickly. 

Despite the head retention, this is a pretty bubbly lively beer & it does the dance between heavy beer and bubbly prickly palate very well. 

Enjoyable, and unbeatable for the price.

Poured from twelve ounce corked and caged bottle into Riedel Overture beer glass. A fresh fragrance of potpourri rushes up to the fore with heaps of dried lavender and violet, black forest cherry skins dashed with powdered sugar, and, of course, plum sauce. Head appears as a shadowy wisp of a ring that fizzles into spotty lace and a bronze metal body. Dense fruit cake fills the palate, deconstructing into dried dark stone fruit skins, gingerbread, and culminating with huge malt that settles into flavors between coffee cake and tiramisu. Thick enough consistency that coats the tongue with a velvet-rich texture. Well-balanced and one of the best entries of a Belgian style from an American brewery that Ive tasted.

Poured from a bottle into trappist glass.  Intense dark red brown appearance, but for some reason the head was very subdued and thin.  Not sure if I poured it wrong, but Im just surprised there wasnt more to it...not as surprised when I smell it.  Huge fruit aroma, vanilla, yeast funk, and a big boozey overtone. The ABV is probably why the head was so thin. Taste is dominated by some alcohol bitterness, but lots of fig, plum/raisin, banana, sweet brown sugar.  As it warms up, it seems to get a little sweeter with some tea leaf in there too.  Pretty good but a little harsh I think.

13 oz., heavy, corked & caged bottle, poured to a snifter at Lunar Brewing Co., showing some clarity to the dark brown, ruby highlighted color, with a very modest, off white/light tan head that reduced quickly to a thin ring, splashed up some spots & streaks of lacing on the sides of the glass, along with a leggy film. The aroma started with alcohol presence, followed by sweet plum/prune, raisin, spice, and caramelly malt. Full bodied, with decent carbonation to project the notes, the flavor mimmicked the aroma notes well, then added some tartness and alcohol warmth. A very nice sipper!

Happy St Pattys Day 2013.  First big beer of the day.  Bottle.  Pours nearly black with some light coming through.  A big carbonation head jumped up and quickly dissipated with a light film.  The aroma has a ton of dark fruits.  Plums, obviously, raisins, brown sugar.  A really nice smelling quad.  The taste has a nice sweetness up front that does has a lot of plum flavor.  There is a rich brown sugar trail following.  The alcohol is very well hidden.  A great quad at a great price.

Aroma is very subtle. Maybe plum, caramel and bread

Appearance is dark brown with a slight reddish tiny

Taste is plum, stone fruit, caramelized candy and Belgian phenolics

Palate is much lighter than expected. I paired it with a porter house and it was very complimentary but not overwhelming. 

Very good beer. I will buy several bottles and cellar a few. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and thin, creamy beige head; decent retention and spare lacing. Aroma is plums, cookie and caramel malts, floral hops, spicy alcohol, figs, raisins, and light chocolate. Flavor is dark fruit esters and sweet malts forward with floral hops, light vanilla, light oak, and fresh dough; dry, lightly sweet finish. Med/full body and low carbonation.

Dark amber/purple pour with a ruby/purple hue and beige head .... aroma of dark fruits, plums/figs, caramel malt, sugary sweet and slightly boozy ... taste is of dark fruits, sugar plums for sure, figgy, caramel/roasted malts, brown sugar, chocolate malts and some heat/boozy ... taste and smell are similar ... lots of flavors good stuff just a tad sugary and boozy
Bottle from Capitol Beer,Sacramento. Pours near black with an attractive tan head and a plum and treacle aroma. There is a rich dark molasses flavor with a plum and oak finish. Complex and tasty.
Bottle poured into glass. Brown murky pour with very little head. Aroma is a mix between plums, dark fruit and malt. Flavor is a little herby mixed with chocolate. Needless to say I dig it.

12.7 ounce corked bottle with cage poured into the Ovila gold rimmed chalice glass. Nice tan head that slowly subsides but stays around thanks to the proper glassware. Sweet malty aroma of prunes and currants. Well balanced complex mouth feel and taste of ripe prune and plums with some banana and yeast. The alcohol is well hidden and this beer becomes better towards the end as it warms. Nice sweet lingering finish. One of the best quads made in America.

Grape and Gourmet C&C bottle. Thank you for making this in smaller bottles. Interesting aroma that seems dusty but some fruity sweetness lurking in the background. Nice quad with yeast, spice, alcohol, and sweetness in the finish. Good, maybe a little up front with the alcohol. Very cool concept.

Poured a thin tan head on a dark brown, almost black body.
The aroma is wonderful and deep. Candy, plums, caramel and wet grain all dance around.
The taste is long. Fairly sweet throughout with a mild lemon bitterness in the middle, the finish is warm alcohol.
The texture is heavier with low carbonation.
Its pretty good, but the taste hasnt caught up with the rest of it.
Deep brown in color with a soft off-white head.  Sweet with a roast edges and dry fruit and plum flavor.  The  finish is roasty and alcohol-warm finish.  Raisiny sweet and roasty aroma.

Pours dark brown with red tinted highlights that are barely visible and a small off-white head.  Aroma of raisins, grape juice, cinnamon, brown sugar, and wood.  Flavor of brown sugar, maple, raisins, lots of dark sweet fruit, and cinnamon.  Finishes slightly dry, but not too much, with earth and fruit.  Pretty heavy-bodied and the carbonation is high enough, but the mouthfeel just isnt quite up to the Belgian classics.  Still, I think the flavor profile is great here, and is free of anything I dislike.
I really enjoyed the plum flavor in this one. It definitely kicked it up a few notches compared to the barrel aged ovila quad.

Bottle.  Clear dark maroon color, with an off-white head.  Toffee, dark malts, sweetness, raisin, plum, prune, light brown sugar, some spicy yeast.  The beer is pretty boozy, with lots of alcohol in the finish.  It really doesnt taste any more "plumy" then most other quads.  The carbonation is pretty high and is prickly on the tongue.  Decent, but I was expecting it to be better.

12.7 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice biege head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, spice, and yeast.  Taste is plums, cherries, caramel, yeast, spice, and a bit of alcohol.  Was a pleasant surprise.  Wish I had more.  Very good.
This is a superb Belgian Ale by Sierra Nevada.  Im not sure that MORE plum is necessary in a quad, but somehow, it wasnt too overwhelming.

Deep mahogany brown in color... Aroma of candi sugar, caramel... Flavor is sweet caramel, Belgian malts, notes of tobacco, fig, and plum... Slight yeast on the finish with warmth of alcohol... Delicious

Probably the best beer I have had in years. I never wanted it to end. Poured a deep purple with minimal head. Nose was dark fruit without being overbearing.  Flavours of wonderful dark fruit, but again, very, very subtle. It may have plum, but it was used perfectly.

Its definately one of my favorite beers of 2013 so far. Its a dark beer but not too heavy! The hints of plum and banana were subtle enough to enjoy with out over-powering the dark coca. Excellent beer but be careful, this beer comes in at 10.3%! A couple of bottles will do.

Pours dark brown/black with a thin tan head.  aroma of sweet bubble gum fruit.  Tastes is dark fruit with slight sweetness and nice dark malt aftertaste.  Overall a very good beer but a little different for the style.

Dark brown color with small off-white ring of a head and messy oily lacing.  Aroma and flavor have huge malts with dark vinous fruitiness.  Definite raisin plum notes in the flavor.  Sweet and spicy- pretty good

12.7oz bottle -pours dark borwnish red with creamy tan head and decent lacing. Nose is dark fruits and brown sugar. Flavor adds old timer fruit. Very dry with a roasted finish. Taste is sweet with a sour finish. Has cough syrup similarities. Oddly enough none of the basement aromas I expect but that is probably due to the youth of this beer. I bet this ages well, but what do I know?  Smoky aftertaste. Cant detect the booze - dangerous.

Dark mahogany pour with a thin beige head that fades to a ring. Aroma is brown sugar, sweet dark fruits, spice, and slight alcohol. Taste is dough, dates, spice, and alcohol with a sharpness to it. A little tannic as well. Overall pretty good.

Draft at Churchkey. Pours a beautiful deep burgundy color with small head and good lacing. Nose and flavor rife with dark fruit notes of plum, fig, hints of molasses and cinnamon. Very nicely attenuated, not at all overly sweet. Solid brew.

I was expecting a lot from this and was a little let down. Nice Belgian yeast aroma with a fruity sweetness and alcohol follow-up. The color was a dark malt color that goes with most Quads. The palate was average with a lean toward the heavier side with little to no head. The taste is what got me. It was almost medicinal with a lot of malt and the sweet plums but with a bite that reminded me a little of cough syrup. It improved as I neared the end of the bottle but not enough. It was also strong tasting in the alcohol department. Good but not great.
Dark pour with just a little bit of head. Aroma is malty and chocolate. Boozy and nice, the beer has dark fruit tones.

500mL cork & caged bottle poured to my Chimay goblet. Dark, almost black in color w/ ruby tinges. Big flavors of sweet, dark malts, lots of dark, dried fruits, brown sugar. Can definitely get notes from the plums. Nicely done brew.

On tap. Dark brown with almost no head. Sweet chocolate, plum, candy sugar, brown sugar, and roasted grain aroma and taste with a thick slightly sticky palate and a strong sugary plum taste to the finish.
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Wonderful fruity taste to this quad and a very well balanced taste.
Dark coffee black with red highlights, thin head. Big Belgian nose, dark fruits, sugars. Very sweet but dry attack, long lingering finish. Warming to the belly. Yumm.

10oz pour at Tylers Apex. Great aroma, sweet. Chocolate, plum, candied sugar.. dark orangy brown color. Good head, faded quick. Mlittle to no lace. Sweet flavor.  Medium body, oily creamy mouthfeel. Sweet finish. Darn tasty. Lots with the aroma. Flavor only tar less good, but still very good. Wonderful really. Plum adds so much more to it.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
A - Dark red-brown with a finger of frothy khaki-brown head. Fades normal.

S - Sweet dark caramel malts with plums, raisins, other dark fruits, Belgian yeast, clove, pepper, spices, and a bit of booze.

T - Sweet dark caramel malts, plums, raisins, other dark fruits, Belgian yeast, clove, pepper, other spices, candi sugar, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Nicely balanced Quad with great mouthfeel.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark brown with medium beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is candy sugar raisin and plums. Medium mouthfeel with yeast brown sugar and light plum flavor. Alcohol present but not overpowering. A good quad from Sierra Nevada.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is full of plums, other dark fruit and alcohol. The flavor is very similar. I really like all of the sweet, sugary fruit notes I get in the flavor. I get cherries, grapes and plums. There is also a bit of yeast and cinnamon, as well as some alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very nice overall.

Extremely dark brown body with intensly vibrant cranberry highlights, large, light khaki, very tightly structured head falls to a ring and nearly solid sheet with a few bridges of lace; getting more and more plumb juice as this warms helping to cut the sweetness of the candy sugar and adding a nice twist to the bready notes, very dark and deep with a range of fruit, faint pepper, and thankfully not cloying, theres a solid layer of bubblegum I could stand to have less of; not incredibly complex, but plenty of well integrated, complimentary characteristics; Ill get more of this to see how it matures
Read my Olivia review.,...  Ill transfer it over later....

12.7oz bottle from West Lakeview Liquors. Pours a rich, deep brown colored body with a slight mahogany hue. Thin, fizzy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is rich caramel and dark fruits with a real nice plummy note. Some yeasty spice, bread, brown sugar, phenols, and touches of cocoa. Flavor is similar. Rich and malty with lots of caramel, some bready toffees and brown sugar, raisins, prunes, plums, and phenols. Cocoa grows a touch towards the end as well as a nice spiciness from the yeast before this finishes very clean, spicy, and dry, but well balanced with a rich caramel and plummy dark fruit. Lengthy aftertaste with a nice warming alcohol note following a medium-full, somewhat sticky body and a soft, moderately lively carbonation. Overall, this is a really awesome quad. Sweet, but not cloying in the least bit with plenty of plummy dark fruits, a solid yeast spiciness, and a very pleasing alcohol note. Excellent beer.

This beer is very solid, not really a big belgian guy but I really enjoyed this beer. this beer is very sweet and sugary. The beer had a very enticing aroma, raisin aroma for sure. I really liked that it didnt have big bready belgian taste.

nose: dominated by dark candied fruits, Look: A very dark foreboding deep purple. Taste; Luscious tones of those dark fruits esp Plums and Belgian yeast. A touch of spice. nice. no real alcohol except in a gentle warming. Palate: Pleasing brew. Ive had way better Quads but this Id buy again. Just a pleasing addition to the style.

Tap at the brewpub. Pours very dark brown/black in the wide Ovila goblet. Sort of garnet when viewed through the edges. Beige head. Aroma seems fruity. Med + body. Flavor is plummy and malty. Initial flavor has a strong aspect - almost pepper/spice. Heat is noticeable and contributes to the strong flavor. Seems to develop chocolate notes. Finishes nearly dry, fruity and not very bitter. Excellent. Got 4 bottles in the shop!
Pricey 12oz bottle into tulip glass.  Plum and fig hit you over the head, but shortly yields to caramel and spice notes.  Unbelievably smooth for 10.2 %!  Thick and rich palate.  I enjoyed it.
Caramel, plum and boozy aromas. Plum juice, toffee and Belgian yeast flavors. Overall a very good Belgian quad.
Draft. Dark ruby purple color, small tan head. Aroma of dates, raisins, figs, plums. Taste is sweet dark fruit, port wine, raisins. A big beer, but very tasty.
Cute little corked bottle pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of plums and a touch of caramel. Taste of caramel, chocolate and plums. Sweet but not cloying. Great for dessert.
Bottle from Casa De Oro. Deep ruby in color. Sweet candy nose. Some sweet dark fruit. Almost vinous. Sweet dark fruit up front. Reminds me a little of wine. Pretty rich and full flavored.

375, corked and baled. Thanks c! Pours a murky dark eggplant mahogany. Loose creamy tan head. Big sweet plum nose mixed with plastics and hot swimming pool toys. Creamy medium body, almost thick, with very little carb. Plums, sweet dark sugar, and a bit of plastic on the mid palate. Tangy, estery finish.

(bottle) Pours a clear dark red with a thin off-white head that retains well.  Aroma has plum written all over it, and smells exactly like a ripe Italian plum.  There are underlying scents of bread and brown sugar, but the plum is the dominant feature, which certainly isnt off-putting in any way.  No real trace of the high alcohol in the aroma.  The flavor is a big let down in comparison to the pleasant plumminess of the aroma, and it reminds me of a sugar-free jam thats been diluted in water.  The flavor and texture is very thin, weak, and it lacks the substantial heft and breadiness that are normally present within most quads.  Peppery alcohol (or is it the yeast?) leaves an obnoxious sting on the finish and interrupts what was a decent finish, as the plum does intensify somewhat mid-palate.  Overall the aroma was spot on, but the flavor left much to be desired.

(Draught) clear very deep brown, ring of fine tan bubbles. Nose of brown sugar, dark dried fruit, spiced, Belgian yeast, cinnamon, and pumpernickel. Taste is very sweet, plum, candi sugar in abundance, probably would be better with more carbonation and if it was dry.

Crimson pour with garnet highlights and a thin eggshell head.  Raisin, plum, prune and fig in the nose accompanied by honey-baked biscuit, brown sugar and toffee.  Subtle spice of nutmeg, cinnamon, and all-spice are there along side the dark fruit.  Surprised by the ABV...didnt really distract at all.

What the fuck is a sugar plum? 12.7 oz corked and caged bottle. Pours dark dark mahogany and looks ruby red under the light; has a medium beige head with decent retention. Aroma is doughy with accents of dark fruit and alcohol; what smells like faint Christmas spices and caramel come through as it warms. Taste is sweet and savory with a lightly sour finish; boozy. Medium to soft carbonation. This is pretty harsh. I need to get another bottle to age. It has to get better than this over time. Addendum: okay, this beer did get better as it sat. Its caramel and fruit character became much more pronounced and the booziness seemed to dial down a bit. I still think it needs some time in the cellar, though. My original score was 6,4,6,4,13 = 3.3.

12.7oz. corked bottle.  Dark burgundy with decent lacing.  10.2% ABV listed on bottle.  Mild moderate aromas of brown sugars and plums.  The flavors stand out more with plums and booze.  This has a dull sweetness with some bananas in the background.  The flavors blend together quit well.  Finishes with some heat.  Very enjoyable.  Thankfully the yeast flavors do not linger into the finish.  Overall a soft blend of wonderful flavors.

Poured dark brown with a moderate khaki head.  Nose had lots dark sweetness, toasted caramel, grains and dark fruits.  Thick, full mouthfeel, good carbonation with wick away the booziness and intense malt sweetness. Very malty so it was complex, yet not cloying.  Dark grains, big fruitiness, dark fruits, somewhat vinous and even a hint of cocoa.  Warming alcohol heat in the finish.  Very nice Quad. Kudos to Sierra Nevada here.

12.7 oz. bottle poured into my Duvel glass. Pours mahogany brown with a tight khaki beige head that dissipates to a thin film on top. Aroma is sweet candied sugar caramel faint bananas and dark fruit with some notes of juicy fruit. Taste is sweet and tart with plum caramel sugars and roasted malt some nuttiness and bitterness. Palate is medium with a clean crisp feel and a gentle warming dry finish. This is very nice!
Draft. Black with a small head. Sweet nose.  Taste is very sweet and heavy alcohol.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Dark clear cola colored pour with a reddish tinge, very small tan head quickly dissapating. Aroma of grapes, plums and some spice. Taste of malts, molasses, plums, a touch of licorice and a faint hop bitterness on the finish. Full bodied, medium carbonation, sweet but not at all cloying, excellent beer.

From a 12.7oz corked bottle, labeled 10.2%. Awesome label. Says its a collaboration with the "Abbey of New Clairvaux" on the label. Dark brown / red but still clear color. Thin khaki head, leaves decent lace. Dark fruit and plums in the nose. Awesome sweet plum flavor. Its just the right type of sweetness, sugary but not cloying, like a nice plum jam or something. Works well with the natural dark fruit flavors of a quad, with little light spice flavors. Alcohol is hard to notice, there is very little bite, more just a nice sweetness in the finish. I think there must be two different versions of this, my bottle tastes much more like 10.2% than 12.7%. [Edit: On the other hand, the back of my bottle does make include the same exact description as the one listed here..] Not very hard to drink. Smooth, lighter carbonation, more dry texture. Kind of soft. Bigger body. Nice plum and light spice in the aftertaste. Awesome twist on the quadrupel style, it really works here.

Poured dark with no light coming through with a tan 1 finger head. Aroma hits you with sweetness of dark fruits, mainly a raisins and plums with some cherry followed by Belgium yeast and alcohol. On the lips you are hit up front with these dark fruits, mainly raisins followed by the Belgian charectoristics you would expect. A good amount of alcohol is noted on the finish. Mouthfeel was very nice with a silky smooth finish and hardly any carbonation, making this the best part of this beer to be honest.

A clear dark burgundy beer with an ephemeral tan head.  The aroma is mild with plum,  caramel malt, Munich malt, pale chocolate malt, banana and some band aid which thankfully disappeared after a few swirls. The flavor is like the aroma, but it doesnt quite earn tasty status.  Low bitterness.  Id like it better with a mild raisin note.  Its a good deal at $13.99 per 4 pack. Smooth and boozy with bonus banana burps.  Not a good beer to judge by having just one beer.  It became more enjoyable after 24 ounces were consumed.
From the bottle, a brownish pour and somewhat violet hue, aroma is sweet with sugary fruits.  Taste has some plums in the finish.  Pretty good.
Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks good; a fairly opaque dark brown with light beige lacing. Smells and tastes solid; candied dark fruit. Good on the palate. Good beer.

Bottle. Pours an almost-black color with a moderate off-white head. Nose has some slight sweetness with a hint of sour and is darkly fruity. Taste has a subtle hint of roasting with other malts helping. A small bit of sweetness underlies some sour fruit notes. Amazing beer.

12.7 oz bottle- Dark brown pour with decent creme head. Aroma is plums but somewhat artificial in flavor, sugary,  malty.  For a 10+ ABV, no alcohol smell or flavor. The taste is plum and spices, slightly sweet. Body is good for this style. Im interested to see how this ages but very good now.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 375 ml. corked n caged bottle- Pours a wonderful dark ruby red with a tan head that reduces to a collar and some islands. Aroma is I think sugar plums, sugary and other dark fruits, malt, really no alcohol in the aroma surprisingly. The taste is dark fruits, the plums really resonate, spices, sugary, but not really sweet. Body is full, carbonation is kind of low, which surprises me. Overall I honestly think this needs some age, it was just released, even a couple months would do it wonders I think. I believe and hope my score will go up in the months ahead, I do have three more bottles. 7-26-13 Re-rate- Honestly I am only doing this because I said I would rate it again, but I dont think my scores are going to change, 6 months later and my opinion hasnt changed, nice beer though, but it has seemed to mellow a bit.
